text: He hath shewed his people the power of his works, that he may give them the heritage of the heathen.
text_kjv: He hath shewed his people the power of his works, that he may give them the heritage of the heathen.
text_niv: He has shown his people the power of his works,giving them the lands of other nations.
text_esv: He has shown his people the power of his works, in giving them the inheritance of the nations.
text_nlt: He has shown his great power to his peopleby giving them the lands of other nations.
text_msg: He proved to his people that he could do what he said:Hand them the nations on a platter—a gift!
text_nasb: He has made known to His people the power of His works, In giving them the heritage of the nations.
context: Psalm 111 is an acrostic psalm, meaning each verse begins with a successive letter of the Hebrew alphabet, demonstrating thoroughness and completeness. It is a song of praise and thanksgiving to God for His attributes and actions. The phrase 'the heritage of the heathen' carries significant weight considering Israel's historical context. God promised Abraham the land of Canaan, then inhabited by various Canaanite tribes often described as 'heathen' because of their polytheistic worship and practices, which often included morally repugnant rituals and beliefs. This land wasn't simply real estate; it represented God's blessing and a covenant promise. During the Exodus, God dramatically displayed His power, delivering the Israelites from Egyptian bondage and leading them through the wilderness. The 'power of his works' refers directly to these miraculous events, demonstrating God's sovereignty over nature and human powers. The conquest of Canaan, therefore, was not merely a military endeavor but a divinely ordained reclaiming of what God had promised. The term 'heathen' often carried negative connotations, emphasizing their idolatry and moral depravity, contrasting sharply with the monotheistic faith and ethical standards God demanded of Israel. Therefore, this verse is rooted deeply in the narrative of God's covenant faithfulness to Israel and His provision for their well-being.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 111:6 encapsulates several crucial concepts. Firstly, it highlights God's consistent demonstration of His power to His people. This isn't merely a display of brute force, but rather a revelation of His character – His omnipotence, faithfulness, and commitment to His covenant. Secondly, the 'heritage of the heathen' isn't simply about territorial acquisition. It symbolizes God's ability to overcome all obstacles and fulfill His promises, even in the face of seemingly insurmountable odds. The Canaanites represented not just opposing armies, but a worldview antithetical to God's. God granting their land to Israel signifies the triumph of His kingdom and His values. The verse speaks to the concept of divine judgment. The dispossession of the Canaanites wasn't arbitrary; it was a consequence of their wickedness (Leviticus 18:24-30). God, in His justice, holds nations accountable. Furthermore, the 'heritage' is given not as a right, but as a gift. Israel didn't earn the land through their own strength, but received it through God's grace. This emphasizes the importance of humility and dependence on God. Ultimately, the verse points to God's sovereignty over all nations and His purpose in history. He is the ultimate King, who determines the rise and fall of empires and the distribution of land according to His will and plan.
application: Today, we no longer engage in physical warfare to dispossess nations. However, the principles embedded in Psalm 111:6 remain profoundly relevant. The 'heritage of the heathen' can be understood metaphorically as the territory of our lives that is dominated by ungodly influences - fear, anxiety, materialism, addiction, or unhealthy relationships. God still desires to 'show his people the power of his works' in these areas. We must recognize that God's power isn't limited to spectacular miracles but is also evident in the quiet, transformative work of the Holy Spirit within us. To claim our 'heritage,' we must actively resist these ungodly influences through prayer, Bible study, and accountability. We are called to live a life that reflects God's values, even when it conflicts with the prevailing culture. This requires courage, discernment, and a willingness to stand firm in our faith. We can look to the examples of believers who have overcome adversity and lived lives of faithfulness. Furthermore, we must be mindful of the dangers of spiritual pride and entitlement. Just as Israel was prone to forgetting God's grace and attributing their success to their own strength, we too can fall into the trap of self-reliance. We must constantly remind ourselves that everything we have is a gift from God and that our dependence on Him is essential for spiritual growth and victory. Evangelism and missions can also be viewed as a modern application of this verse, as we share the Gospel and seek to reclaim lives for Christ, pulling them out of the spiritual darkness of the world.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank You for demonstrating Your power throughout history and in my own life. I acknowledge that You are sovereign over all and that You desire to give me the 'heritage' that is rightfully mine in You. Forgive me for the times I've relied on my own strength and forgotten Your grace. I ask for the courage and discernment to resist the ungodly influences in my life and to stand firm in my faith. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit and empower me to live a life that reflects Your values. Help me to always remember that everything I have is a gift from You and that my dependence on You is essential for spiritual growth and victory. Guide me to boldly share Your message of love, hope, and redemption with those still living in spiritual darkness, so they too can experience your powerful works. In Jesus’s name, I pray, Amen.

faqs.answer: No, this verse does not justify taking land from other people today. The context was a specific covenant with Israel concerning a promised land. The actions were under direct divine command in a unique historical situation. Applying it to modern territorial disputes is a misinterpretation of scripture.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Does this verse justify taking land from other people today?

faqs.answer: Modern 'heathen' influences can be understood as any beliefs or practices that contradict biblical values. Examples include excessive materialism, unrestrained hedonism, moral relativism, and any form of idolatry (putting anything before God). Discernment is key in identifying these influences.
faqs.question: Q2: What are some modern 'heathen' influences we should avoid?

faqs.answer: We can see God's power at work today through answered prayers, experiencing inner transformation, observing acts of kindness and compassion, witnessing healing and restoration, and recognizing the beauty and order of creation. Paying attention to these signs cultivates a deeper awareness of God's presence.
faqs.question: Q3: How can we 'see' God's power at work today as Psalm 111:6 suggests?

faqs.answer: Grace is central because the heritage isn't earned but freely given by God. Israel didn't deserve the land, nor did they conquer it by their own power. It was a gift rooted in God's covenant faithfulness, highlighting His unmerited favor and love. Similarly, our spiritual inheritance is granted through grace.
faqs.question: Q4: How does grace relate to receiving 'the heritage of the heathen'?

faqs.answer: No, the 'heritage' extends beyond material possessions or land. It encompasses spiritual blessings, such as salvation, forgiveness, peace, joy, and eternal life. It's about inheriting God's kingdom and participating in His divine nature. Material blessings can be part of it, but are secondary.
faqs.question: Q5: Is the 'heritage' only about material possessions or land?
